Yes, during the Athens Paralympic Games, several athletes were suspended or disqualified for doping violations just like in many other Paralympic Games.

The International Paralympic Committee (IPC) is responsible for overseeing anti-doping efforts and ensuring that Paralympic athletes compete in a clean and fair environment. They work in partnership with the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) and accredited anti-doping organizations to carry out testing and uphold anti-doping policies.

If an athlete is suspected of violating anti-doping policies during the Games, the relevant authorities carry out testing to confirm or refute the violation. If a doping violation is confirmed, the athlete is disqualified from the competition, their results are nullified, and they may face additional sanctions, depending on the severity of the violation.

During the Athens Paralympic Games, several athletes tested positive for banned substances, and they were subsequently disqualified from their events. In some cases, sanctions such as suspensions, fines, or bans from future competitions were imposed on the athletes.

The IPC and WADA work together to ensure that anti-doping policies are enforced effectively, and that clean sport is promoted in the Paralympic movement. The organizers of the Athens Paralympic Games would have followed these procedures to ensure that the Games were conducted fairly and with integrity.
